thread.author: James Okafor
thread.body: Should we define what "local-first" means more precisely here? The Ink & Switch definition has 7 properties — we only satisfy 5 of them right now.

thread.author: Sarah Chen
thread.body: Good point. I've linked to the full paper in the appendix. For this doc, I think the plain-language version is fine — the audience is engineering leadership, not academics.

thread.author: Maya Patel
thread.body: The 18k ops/s number is from our benchmarks on M2. Should we include numbers for lower-end hardware too? Our Windows users on spinning disks might see very different results.

thread.author: Tomás Rivera
thread.body: LWW at field level feels too coarse for rich text. What happens when two people bold different words in the same paragraph?

thread.author: Sarah Chen
thread.body: That's handled by the Peritext layer, not LWW. LWW only kicks in for scalar fields like title and metadata. Text content goes through character-level CRDT merge. I'll clarify this in section 2.3.

thread.author: James Okafor
thread.body: We should add a note about compaction. After running Automerge's compaction pass, the overhead drops to ~15% for large documents. Without compaction the history grows unbounded.

thread.author: Ava Kim
thread.body: I've started wireframes for this. The inline diff approach from Google Docs feels too busy — I'm leaning toward a side-by-side panel that only appears when conflicts exist. Will share mocks next week.

thread.author: Tomás Rivera
thread.body: Side-by-side sounds great. Can we also add a "just pick the latest" button for people who don't want to think about it?
